column2: Indonesian pronunciation: [ˈkupaŋ] ; Dutch spelling: Koepang) is the capital of the Indonesian province of East Nusa Tenggara
column3: and had an estimated population in 2019 of 434
column4: 972. It is the biggest city and port on the island of Timor. Kupang is a part of the Timor Leste–Indonesia–Australia Growth Triangle free trade zone.

column1: Kupang was an important port and trading point during the Portuguese and Dutch colonial eras. There are ruins and remnant signs of the colonial presence in the city.

Representatives of the Dutch East India Company (VOC) approached Kupang in 1613 after having conquered the Portuguese fort on Solor. At this time the place and its hinterland was governed by a raja of the Helong tribe which claimed descent from Ceram in Maluku. Kupang was well situated for strategic control over parts of Timor
column2: since it was possible to monitor shipping activities to the south coast of the island. Moreover
column3: the Koinino River provided fresh water for the inhabitants. A VOC-Helong agreement was made
column4: but due to the lack of VOC commitment on Timor
column5: Kupang was later influenced by the Portuguese mestizo population of Flores
column6: the Topasses. A Portuguese stronghold was established by the 1640s. However
column7: the VOC was firmly established on Solor in 1646
column8: and renewed contacts with the local raja. In January 1653 a Dutch fortification
column10: was built on a height to the left of the river estuary. Kupang became the base of the Dutch struggle against the Portuguese. After a series of Dutch defeats in 1655
column12: large refugee groups from the VOC allies Sonbai and Amabi settled in the vicinity of Kupang in 1658 and formed small kingdoms on land that traditionally belonged to the Helong. They were followed by two other groups
column13: Amfoan (1683) and Taebenu (1688). The Helong raja remained the "lord of the land" (tuan tanah) but was closely dependent on the VOC authorities. Apart from the old Helong territory
column14: Timor was largely dominated by the Portuguese up to 1749.The Dutch set up a European administration with a chief executive (opperhoofd) and a council. Affairs with the indigenous populations were regulated through regular meetings (vergaderingen). The Kupang administration handled affairs with the VOC-allied islands Rote
column15: Savu and Solor. Chinese traders and artisans settled by the early 18th century and soon became indispensable for the economic life. The town area was also settled by various indigenous groups from the region
column16: and by mardijkers who were non-whites under Dutch jurisdiction. In 1752 the population was 827 Christians and an unspecified number of non-Christians. The political importance of Kupang on a Timor-wide level increased greatly in 1749 when the Topasses were decisively defeated by the Dutch and their allies
column17: which led to the extension of VOC influence over wide areas of western and central Timor. Nevertheless
column18: some of this influence contracted after 1761 due to incompetence and inaction on the part of the colonial administration.

column1: Kupang was the final destination of William Bligh who was set adrift in an open boat following the Mutiny on the Bounty (1789). The mutiny took place about 30 nautical miles (56 km) from Tofua in the Tonga islands. Lt William Bligh navigated the overcrowded 23 foot (7 m) open launch on an epic 41-day voyage first to Tofua and then to the West Timor city of Kupang equipped only with a quadrant
column2: pocket watch and a compass — but no charts to navigate from. He recorded the distance as 3
column3: 618 nautical miles (6710 km). He passed through the difficult Torres Strait along the way and landed on 14 June. The only casualty of his voyage was a crewman named John Norton who was stoned to death by the natives of Tofua
column4: the first island they tried to land on. News of the journey of Captain Bligh inspired the escape of a party of convicts from the penal colony at Sydney Cove
column5: Australia. A group of nine convicts and two children
column7: stole a small uncovered government boat and escaped from Port Jackson
column12: 026 km).As a consequence of the occupation of the Netherlands at the hands of the French revolutionary armies in 1795
column13: the VOC possessions in East India were attacked by British forces. Kupang was assaulted in 1797. The British were eventually expelled although the town was reduced to rubble. A new British attack was likewise defeated in 1811. After the British occupation of Java
column14: Kupang finally surrendered in January 1812. The British returned the town to the Dutch in 1816. The political strongman in the early 19th century was Jacobus Arnoldus Hazaart who governed Dutch Timor as Resident in 1810–12
column15: 1814–18 and 1819–32 and handled matters without much interference from the colonial government in Batavia. During his time the Christian mission made a deeper impact through the efforts of the missionary Reint LeBruyn (1799-1829). The town was opened to foreign trade in 1825 and fees were abolished three years later. Kupang was often visited by whalers from Britain and North America. However
column16: the relocation of whale hunting areas made Kupang a less lively place in the late 19th century
column17: although it was a free port after 1866. The five small kingdoms that surrounded the town area (the Helong kingdom of Kupang
column20: Taebenu and Funai) were merged into the zelfbesturend landschap (self-ruling territory) Kupang in 1917
column21: but in spite of the name it did not include the town itself. From 1918 to 1955 it was governed by the Nisnoni family
column22: a branch of the Sonbai Dynasty.In the early twentieth century
column23: the city was used for landing and refueling by long distance airplane flights between Europe and Australia. It was occupied by the Japanese in 1942–1945
column24: and much of the old town was destroyed by allied bombing. During the time of the Indonesian revolution 1945-1949 there was nationalist agitation in Kupang
column25: but no actual fighting. Kupang was part of the colonial pseudo-state East Indonesia that was set up by the Dutch
column26: and the town area was included in the zelfbesturend landschap Kupang. The latter was phased out after the achievement of independence. Kupang was an important location during the conflict in East Timor
column28: as well as the militias. The camps around Kupang were also of significant impact on the city.

column2: the city was made the seat of the Diocese of Kupang. In 1989 the diocese was elevated to become the Archdiocese of Kupang.

column1: Kupang's climate is a tropical wet and dry climate (Aw) by the Köppen climate classification. Unlike many cities outside Indonesia with this climate
column2: Kupang's temperature varies a little between the hotter summer season (October to March) and the cooler winter season (April to September). October is the hottest month (average temperature 28.8 °C /83.8 °F) and July the coolest (average temperature 26.1 °C /79.0 °F). The city has a distinct wet season and dry season. January is the wettest month (precipitation total 386 millimetres/15.2 in). August and September are the driest months (precipitation total 2 millimetres /0.079 in)

column1: Kupang is a multi-ethnic city composed of the ethnic groups of West Timor
column5: and immigrants from Ambon and from other parts of Indonesia. Based on data from the Central Bureau of Statistics of Indonesia for 2019

column3: a kota (city) which has the same status as a regency (kabupaten) within the Indonesian administrative system.  The chief officers are the mayor and deputy mayor
column4: elected officials who hold office for five years.  The current mayor and deputy mayor are Jefri Riwu Kore and Harmanus Man who were sworn into office by the governor of the province of East Nusa Tenggara
column6: in Kupang on 1 August 2017. They will hold office for the period 2017–2022.

column1: The formal sector of the manufacturing sector in the Kupang area is mainly based on the cement industry.  The export and import of goods from the local port is also an important part of the regional economy.  Local service sector activities (trading
column3: food and drinks) also employ significant numbers of people in the informal sector.

column1: Fish exports from East Nusa Tenggara are centralized through the Port of Fisheries in Tenau
column5: and Thailand are the top four fish export destinations.

column1: Kupang is the first port of call for yachts in the annual Sail Indonesia rally which starts in Darwin
column2: Australia towards the end of July each year. In 2006 about 100 yachts from around the world took part in the rally. From Kupang yachts head north to Alor and then stop at various ports in Indonesia over a period of about three months ending up in Singapore.

column1: Kupang City hosts some of the progressive civil society organisations such as Pikul Foundation
column2: TF Indonesia and CIS Timor. Think tanks organisation also exist in the city and one of the leading think tank is the Institute of Resource Governance and Social Change.

column1: Kupang's El Tari Airport (formerly "Penfui Airport") serves domestic flights to several cities in Indonesia
column2: as well as an international route to Dili

column1: The airport previously operated direct flights to Darwin
column3: but this was discontinued along with the Dili route in the 1990s
column4: due to alleged human rights violations by the Indonesian Armed Forces in East Timor. The Kupang-Dili route was resumed on 15 December 2017

column1: Kupang harbour is a harbour in Kupang that can serve both cargo and passenger ships.  Passengers typically advance through Kupang to destinations such as Ruteng
column3: Kalabahi and others.  Currently the Commercial Port is located in Tenau and Bolok
column4: which is a Kupang regency.  Kupang Namosain is a natural sea port that is now laid out better.  This port serves timber ships heading to Rote
column5: Semau and areas around the city of Kupang.  Previously the port was also used by fishermen to unload their catches.  Kupang Harbor is an old sea port now berthing sailboats from abroad and has become a stopover in sailing Indonesia from Darwin

column1: Land transport system in Kupang is served by minibus transportation commonly called bemo.
